item.title: UFL: How To Get Festive Kits & Items
item.description:
Quick Links

  • How To Get Free Festive Kits & Items In UFL
  • All UFL Festive Store Packs
  • All Available UFL Festive Items

UFL provides a wide range of items to personalize your club, allowing players to hit the pitch with a distinctive style that adds color and fun to your gameplay. To celebrate the holiday season, UFL has introduced an exclusive, limited-time collection to mark Christmas and New Year in style.

This collection features a range of holiday-themed items, including the Fairylight and Snow Whirl balls, The Sleighmaker, Elfium, Field Glow, and Gingerman kits, and the Elven Step boots festive designs, all available for players to earn. Here’s how you can get your hands on all the festive kits and items to embrace the holiday spirit at UFL .

How To Get Free Festive Kits & Items In UFL

To claim the free Festive Kits in UFL , players need to complete designated challenges within specified time frames or purchase them from the in-game store . The festive cosmetic collection will remain available from December 19 until March 1 , giving players plenty of time to unlock these exclusive items.

Each collection kit comes with its own unique challenge, which must be completed before the expiration date to claim the reward. You can find these special quests in the game’s Challenges section, making it easy to monitor your progress after every match.

Goal Maker Challenge (December 19 – December 26)

  • Challenge: Score 100 goals
  • Reward: Field Glow Kit

Victory Streak Challenge (December 26 – January 2)

  • Challenge: Win 30 matches
  • Reward: Gingerman Kit + Mittens

Brick Wall Challenge (January 2 – January 9)

  • Challenge: Win 10 matches without conceding a goal
  • Reward: Red Card Rudolf Kit

In addition to earning holiday-themed content through special challenges, players can purchase items directly from the in-game store . While entirely optional, this allows for quicker access to the festive items.

If you unlock any purchased content by completing its corresponding challenge , the game will refund the value of that specific reward .

All UFL Festive Store Packs

Although the rewards can be earned through challenges, UFL also offers three exclusive festive-themed packs available for purchase in the PlayStation and Xbox stores . These packs include seasonal cosmetic items along with additional bonuses. While they are optional, these provide a convenient way for players to quickly access the festive rewards without the need to complete the challenges.

Field Glow Pack ($9.99)

  • Glow Kit
  • 1-day Premium Status
  • 10,000,000 Credit Points (CP)
  • 500 League Points (LP)

Gingerman Pack ($17.99)

  • Gingerman Kit
  • Snow Whirl Ball
  • 3-day Premium Status
  • 50,000,000 Credit Points (CP)
  • 500 League Points (LP)

Red Card Rudolf Pack

  • Red Card Rudolf Kit
  • Mittens
  • Fairylight Ball
  • 7-day Premium Status
  • 100,000,000 Credit Points (CP)
  • 1,050 League Points (LP)

All Available UFL Festive Items

Here's a list of all the festive items in UFL :

In-game look

Item name

Category

Mittens

Gloves

Gingerman

Kit

The Sleighmaker

Kit

Field Glow

Kit

Snow Whirl

Ball

Fairylight

Ball

Elven Step

Boots

item.title: 6 Video Games That Let You Fight Santa
item.description:
Summary

  • Santa goes rogue in some video games, adding chaos to Christmas spirit, even for jolly old St. Nick.
  • Games like Saints Row IV, Terraria, and Dead Rising 4 feature twisted and evil Santas to face.
  • From murderous Santas with axes to Santa mini-bosses morphing into robots, these games offer unique holiday challenges.

Santa Claus may be the face of holiday cheer, but even the nicest guy in the North Pole can have a breaking point. Sometimes, jolly old St. Nick goes rogue — and let’s be real, that’s not exactly great for the Christmas spirit. And when that actually happens, it’s not just a holiday hiccup; it’s a full-blown crisis that demands attention. Even Santa shouldn't get a free pass for ruining Christmas.

Video games are absolute pros when it comes to throwing convention out the window for a unique and unusual idea. The "Santa gone rogue" trope lets players step into the chaos, putting their own spin on saving (or just surviving) Christmas. Whether these games lean into humor, memes, or even dark irony, they all agree on one thing: not even Kris Kringle is above being stopped when things go too far.

6 Saints Row 4

Fake Santa Impersonator Named Clawz

Saints Row IV in itself is not Christmas-related, but it has a special DLC released in 2013 fully centered on restoring the holiday spirit. It's called "How the Saints Save Christmas" and is exactly what it is advertised to be.

The story centers on Playa, the protagonist, who doesn’t believe in Santa Claus but is forced to step in when the holiday icon is impersonated by his evil counterpart, Clawz. To save Christmas, the Saints must defeat Clawz and restore the holiday spirit. It’s everything you’d expect from Saints Row IV — absurd, hilarious, and completely committed to the chaos, with the Saints somehow pulling off a Christmas miracle despite their own doubts about the big man in red.

5 Slay Bells

Murderous Santa With A Massive Axe

Released

2020

Dev(s)

Blake McKinnon Productions

Platforms

Windows, macOS

Slay Bells is an indie horror slasher game released in 2020. It looks pretty unassuming at first, but once players have their first encounter with the antagonist — none other than Santa Claus himself — they get their first taste of pure, unbridled horror.

The game gets hearts racing with how quick-paced and dark it is. The player character has to run through a massive but dark city while being on the lookout for a murderous Santa in pursuit. The Santa in question isn't even a massive brooding individual — he's just really fast and can catch players by surprise. The axe in his hand and the absolutely terrifying ambiance of the environment do not help with the fear factor, either.

4 Terraria

Terminator-Esque Santa With A Lot Of Damage Output

Every gamer up to speed with the industry knows Terraria is NOT a Christmas game. That doesn't mean it doesn't get holiday events like most popular games do during the Christmas season. Terraria has a hard mode event called Frost Moon based on the holidays (that is, fortunately, present all year round and not only during the season) that features a rather creepy-looking Santa mini-boss called Santa-NK1.

Despite being a mini-boss, Santa NK1 is fairly challenging to get past. He has one of the highest damage outputs in the game with four different unique attacks and a lot of firepower. The Santa also has this creepy feature where when his health goes below 50%, he morphs into this disfigured robotic form, allegedly a reference to the Terminator movies.

3 ClayFighter 63 1/3

Sumo Santa And His Plans For World Domination

Released

1997

Dev(s)

Interplay Productions

Platforms

Nintendo 64

ClayFighter is an old fighting game franchise that debuted in 1993. It features claymation-style stop-motion graphics and doesn’t take itself too seriously. In fact, it acts more like a parody of other high-end and famous fighting games. To do that, it features everything that pokes fun at the genre, from exaggerated monologues to over-the-top action moves and combos.

ClayFighter 63 1/3 is the third game in the series and takes place in a snowy, winter wonderland setting. This gives it a holiday feel, with characters that fit the theme in their own odd ways. One such character is Sumo Santa, an unlockable enemy and the evil counterpart to the real Santa. His plan to take over the world might not scream Christmas spirit, but it definitely adds some chaotic fun to the mix.

2 Boogie Wings

Massive Santa That Yells "Merry Christmas" But Makes It Creepy

Released

1992

Dev(s)

Data East

Platforms

Arcade

Boogie Wings is a side-scrolling shooting game released in 1992 based on WWI. This premise might make the game sound more consequential and self-important than it is, but it's actually a pretty lighthearted, fun game.

While the entire game is based on players trying to battle a group of armed evil scientists, it does have a Christmas-themed level with the final boss being a Santa. The Santa in question is an absolutely menacing unit. He's massive, creepy, and occasionally wishes the players Merry Christmas like a normal Santa — which sort of makes his treason all the more evil.

1 Dead Rising 4

Two Evil Zombified Santas With Holiday-Friendly Weapons

Dead Rising 4 brings the holiday horror with not just one but two twisted takes on Santa Claus. The first, Sadistic Santa, is a maniacal, axe-wielding zombie running amuck in the Willamette Memorial Megaplex. True to his name, he’s as evil as they come — armed with a droppable Electric Axe and backed by an army of zombified elves wielding toy weapons to do his bidding.

The second is called Santa Claws, and he's a multiplayer boss found in Episode 1 of the game at Kiichiro Plaza. He wields a candy cane crossbow and occasionally throws explosives at the player character to keep them on their toes. Although these two Santas are most likely not related, they do make sure the holiday season in Dead Rising 4 is anything but jolly.

item.title: Honkai: Star Rail – The Best Fugue Light Cones
item.description:
Fugue

Fire

Nihility

5-Star

Guides

Build Guide

Level-Up Materials

Team Composition

Best Light Cone

Back to All Characters

Being one of the fan-favorite characters since the Honkai Star Rail 's release, Tingyun joins the playable roster as a 5-star Nihility character under the name of Fugue, following a trend similar to Dan Heng’s transformation into Imbibitor Lunae or the upcoming alternate version of Herta. While Fugue has shifted her path and element, she retains a relatively support-oriented role, though this time she caters more to Break DMG-oriented teams involving characters like Firefly, Rappa, or Boothill. This shift makes her build fundamentally different from other Fire Nihility units like Jiaoqiu or Guinaifen, who serve distinct roles within team compositions.

This divergence is also evident in her light cone options, as Fugue benefits from a unique, albeit somewhat limited, selection of choices. Fortunately, players will find that some accessible F2P options align well with her needs, making it feasible to build her effectively without necessarily relying on her signature light cone in Honkai: Star Rail .

5 Before the Tutorial Mission Starts

HP

ATK

DEF

952

476

330

S5 Passive

Increases the wearer's Effect Hit Rate by 40%. When the wearer attacks enemies that have reduced DEF, regenerates 8 Energy.

Effect Hit Rate isn't as critical for Fugue as it is for some other characters, but maintaining around 60-70% Effect Hit Rate is still valuable to ensure she can reliably apply DEF reduction to high-level enemies. For players looking for an entirely F2P option, Before the Tutorial Mission Starts is an excellent choice for those not wanting to invest heavily in Fugue, while also avoiding the need to equip an Effect Hit Rate main stat body relic.

With sufficient Effect Hit Rate, Fugue will be able to consistently apply DEF reduction and generate energy on her own. However, its worth noting that this light cone doesn't provide any additional team utility, which puts it lower than other options in this list.

4 Fermata

HP

ATK

DEF

952

476

330

S5 Passive

Increases the wearer's Break Effect by 32%, and increases their DMG to enemies afflicted with Shock or Wind Shear by 32%. This also applies to DoT.

A slightly better F2P option for Fugue is Fermata , as it provides the Break Effect stat, which Fugue needs at around 220% or more to maximize her support potential. Equipping Fermata helps alleviate the need to focus too heavily on reaching this threshold through relic sub-stats. However, the second part of Fermata's effect isn't particularly useful for Fugue, as she's not typically paired with DoT-oriented characters like Kafka or Black Swan. Instead, she excels in teams with Hypercarry units, where her focus is on enhancing Break DMG rather than DoT synergy.

3 Solitary Healing

HP

ATK

DEF

1058

529

396

S5 Passive

Increases the wearer's Break Effect by 40%. When the wearer uses their Ultimate, increases DoT dealt by the wearer by 48%, lasting for 2 turn(s). When a target enemy suffering from DoT imposed by the wearer is defeated, regenerates 6.0 Energy for the wearer.

Solitary Healing is relatively on par with Resolution Shines As Pearls of Sweat in terms of Fugue's own damage potential, particularly due to its increase in Break Effect. However, since it doesn't provide direct benefits to the team DMG, it falls behind Resolution Shines As Pearls of Sweat (S5) in Hypercarry team compositions. That said, Solitary Healing can still be a worthwhile option for those seeking a strong F2P choice, especially as a great stat stick due to its higher stats as a 5-star light cone.

2 Resolution Shines As Pearls of Sweat

HP

ATK

DEF

952

476

330

S5 Passive

When the wearer hits an enemy and if the hit enemy is not already Ensnared, then there is a 100% base chance to Ensnare the hit enemy. Ensnared enemies' DEF decreases by 16% for 1 turn(s).

While not entirely F2P like the previous options on the list, Resolution Shines As Pearls of Sweat is the best 4-star light cone for Fugue, especially if players can max superimpose it. This light cone offers additional team benefits by further decreasing enemies' defense and applying a unique debuff, which can be useful in certain situations. However, if players don't have it at S5, it may still be more beneficial to focus on the F2P options mentioned earlier.

1 Long Road Leads Home

HP

ATK

DEF

953

476

661

S5 Passive

Increases the wearer's Break Effect by 60%. When an enemy target's Weakness gets broken, there is a 100% base chance to inflict the "Charring" state on it, which increases its Break DMG taken by 18%, lasting for 2 turn(s). This effect can stack 2 time(s).

Being Fugue's signature light cone, Long Road Leads Home is undoubtedly her best option. However, it isn't as essential as some light cones are for other characters, like Acheron or Boothill . This is because its primary benefits are additional Break Effect and some team-wide buffs. These buffs, while useful, aren't as significant as those provided by Resolution Shines As Pearls of Sweat , meaning players are generally better off focusing on Fugue's eidolons if they wish to invest in her further, or saving resources to pull for upcoming characters.

item.title: Honkai: Star Rail – Fugue Ascension and Trace Materials
item.description:
Fugue

Fire

Nihility

5-Star

Guides

Build Guide

Level-Up Materials

Team Composition

Best Light Cone

Back to All Characters

Fugue has been a highly anticipated character in Honkai: Star Rail , finally joining the roster of playable characters alongside others like Sunday, just before even more eagerly awaited characters are set to arrive in the next major patch. While Fugue shares the same Path and Element as Jiaoqiu, their roles in a team are entirely different. Whereas Jiaoqiu focuses on debuffing enemies to benefit Acheron-centered teams, Fugue is designed to thrive in Break DMG-oriented teams. She brings significant value, especially in situations where players might prefer to utilize Harmony Trailblazer in the Remembrance path instead.

For those who manage to pull Fugue, leveling her to the highest level and maximizing her traces is essential to unlocking her full potential. Fortunately, players have had the opportunity to pre-farm her materials, as these resources have been available for some time. Notably, Fugue’s materials are nearly identical to Jiaoqiu’s, making it especially convenient for players who have already prepared for Jiaoqiu beforehand in Honkai: Star Rail .

Fugue Materials In Honkai: Star Rail

Fugue shares the same materials as Jiaoqiu for her enemy drops, trace materials, and even weekly boss drop requirements, with the only difference being the specific Boss drop. This distinction arises despite both characters belonging to the same element. Here are all materials needed for Fugue's ascension in Honkai: Star Rail .

  • Enemy drop : Immortal Scionette/Aeroblossom/Lumintwig
  • Boss drop : Searing Steel Blade
  • Trace materials : Fiery Spirit / Starfire Essence / Heaven Incinerator
  • Weekly boss drop : Regret of Infinite Ochema

Fugue Ascension Materials In Honkai: Star Rail

Fugue's ascension materials are often found through Luofu enemies. For her boss material, Fugue shares the same boss with another nihility character, Guinaifen and Topaz.

Fugue Trace Materials In Honkai: Star Rail

Fugue will mostly benefit from leveling her Skill and Talent, however, leveling Ultimate is also quite valuable. With that, here's how much of each material Fugue needs to be able to max out these traces.

Fugue Basic Attack Trace Materials

While Fugue's basic attack may not be as valuable, being a low-scaling single target attack, it requires less materials, which is useful for those who want to max level it anyway.

  • Immortal Scionette x6
  • Immortal Aeroblossom x7

Fugue Skill/Talent/Ultimate Trace Materials

Fugue’s skill serves as a support ability, designed to enhance an ally’s Break DMG while also enabling the selected ally to reduce the toughness of enemies, even if the ally’s element does not match the enemy’s weakness. Additionally, her skill reduces the DEF of enemies, making her valuable not only for Break-oriented teams but also for general team compositions seeking to maximize overall DMG. On the other hand, Fugue’s Ultimate is primarily focused on dealing AoE DMG while significantly reducing enemy toughness. Lastly, her talent further facilitates weakness breaking by allowing enemies to be broken more easily and take amplified Super Break DMG, solidifying her role as a versatile support for a variety of team setups involving Firefly, Rappa or Boothill especially.

item.title: Pokemon Pocket: All Mythical Island Supporter Cards, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • Blue and Leaf are new Supporter cards in Pokemon Pocket, with Leaf being the champion due to her universal utility.
  • Blue may seem unnecessary, but he can be a game-changer in crucial moments where survival is key in Pokemon Pocket.
  • Budding Expeditioner is niche and at risk of falling out of the metagame in Pokemon Pocket due to her limited synergy with decks.

The Mythical Island expansion of Pokemon Pocket introduced three new Supporter cards: Leaf, Blue, and Budding Expeditioner. With these additions, the game’s Supporter card roster now features eleven characters.

The addition of Blue and Leaf in the same expansion can’t be an accident. These two characters are long-time rivals in Pokemon lore, with Leaf finally defeating Blue in the final battle during the Indigo League Championship. Now, they’re facing off once again in Pokemon Pocket , this time as Supporter cards vying for a bigger role in the metagame. This raises an inevitable question: Which one is the best? Or, more accurately, which is more likely to become a staple in the META? Here’s a ranking to help answer that.

3 Budding Expeditioner

Neat, but Niche

  • Rarity : 2-Diamond & 2-Star
  • Text : Put your Mew ex in the Active Spot into your hand.

Players are calling Budding Expeditioner “Koga for Mew ex,” which simplifies what this Supporter card does. She lets you return Mew ex to your hand and heal it, making her utility pretty niche and specific.

Since Mew ex’s main attack, Genome Hacking, is a Colorless move, it appears in many decks. As a result, you’ll see plenty of Budding Expeditioners, too, thanks to their strong synergy. However, Budding Expeditioner is just one META-shaking card away from being pushed out of the metagame, which is why she ranks as the least favorable Supporter card in the Mythical Island expansion. If only she could work with more Psychic-Type cards, she’d likely top the list.

2 Blue

The Underdog Supporter

  • Rarity : 2-Diamond & 2-Star
  • Text : During your opponent’s next turn, all of your Pokemon take ten less damage from attacks from your opponent’s Pokemon.

Blue wasn’t well-received in the Pokemon Pocket community when he was released. For many players, he’s still seen as an unnecessary addition and more of a burden in decks than a useful Supporter. However, players need to recognize that Blue is a doomsday card—a Supporter who can turn the tide of a match on rare but crucial occasions.

Imagine this: You’re two turns away from Evolving or building up your main damage dealer on the Bench, while your opponent can one-shot your Active Pokemon and force you to play an unprepared one they can also knock out. But then you play Blue, buying just enough time for your Active Pokemon to survive and complete your build-up strategy. In the next round, you take out your opponent’s Active Pokemon and win. That’s the critical difference Blue can make.

1 Leaf

The True Champion of Mythical Island Supporters

  • Rarity : 2-Diamond & 2-Star
  • Text : During this turn, the Retreat Cost of your Active Pokemon is two less.

Just like in Pokemon lore, Leaf finally defeats Blue, but in Pokemon Pocket , she does so by offering a much better and more universal utility: making two-Energy Retreats free. Leaf is the best Supporter card in the Mythical Island expansion because she’s a plug-and-play card for many decks, especially Charizard ex decks, where Moltres ex might be in the Active Spot. That’s when Leaf steps in, Benching Moltres for free and letting the built-up Charizard ex take its place.

Leaf takes the championship from Blue for one simple reason: it’s not a “doomsday” card. Blue can be a game-changer in rare situations where keeping the Active Pokemon alive for one more round is crucial, but those moments don’t happen often, and Blue won’t always get the chance to shine. In contrast, Leaf is useful in most matches, especially in decks with Pokemon that require two Energy to Retreat—something that comes up frequently.
